sections.title: Physical Improvement
sections.overview: Physical practice approaches for improving croquet skills. Covers the key physical skills: rushing, croquet strokes, and controlled hoop running.

key_concepts.concept: Practice what you're worst at vs what improves odds
key_concepts.description: Common advice suggests practicing weakest skills, but Trimmer argues players should practice whichever skill will most improve odds of winning matches. Sometimes this means focusing on skills you're already decent at if improving them further yields better match results.

The three key skills are: rushing, croquet strokes, and controlled hoop running. Shooting is demoted to a supplement (Appendix D) as many players put too much time into shooting relative to improving other skills.

subsections.title: Rushing
subsections.content: Practice rushing independently. Choose a hoop to rush to, place striker's ball and rush ball, execute rushes. Focuses on starting in corner positions (corner 1, rush to hoop 1; corner 4 to hoop 4, etc.). Emphasizes varying the rush target to different hoops and practicing with different ball positions.

drills.name: Basic Rush Practice
drills.setup: Place rush ball with striker's ball nearby
variations: Practice approach rushes (within 3 yards of target hoop)
tips: Note that hitting range of only 5 yards means approach rushes are most valuable
Practice with combination shots (rather than in isolation) once competent

subsections.title: Croquet Strokes
subsections.content: Large croquet stroke practice requires more walking than rushing practice. Use additional set of balls if possible. Three measurable outcomes: angle, relative distance (ratio), and overall power. Practice from same point adjusting all three to get very good result by fourth attempt.

drills.name: Croquet Stroke Calibration
drills.setup: From near hoop 1, send ball as pioneer to hoop 3 whilst going a yard in front of hoop 2
drills.goal: Be very precise with intended target positions
technique_checks: Are you balanced at end of stroke?
Do you need to free up shoulders and concentrate on feeling grounded in legs?
Is lower hand at same point on mallet shaft with each attempt?
Are you gripping mallet with same tightness?
Are you selecting mallet direction before the stroke itself?

subsections.title: Hoop Running
subsections.content: Controlled hoop running is the skill that is least well recognised by players at the top level. Two reasons for difficulty: (1) physically results are more stochastic due to tiny differences in ball-hoop contact; (2) mentally considerable discipline required to treat practice as equivalent to running hoop on real break.
key_points: Practice controlled hoop-running by trying to not pass a line representing a ball needing to be rushed forward
Recommend trying to run hoops at a pace where if no wire were to be taken, the ball would stop at a particular position (typically further than where you'd ideally want ball to stop)
With time, learn how far you should try to run hoop if no wire were taken

drills.name: Controlled Hoop Running
drills.setup: Ball in front of hoop with imaginary 'rush line' behind
drills.goal: Run hoop with control - ball stops between hoop and the line
drills.progression: Practice until you can run hoops with confidence as if hoop weren't there
drills.mental_aspect: Imagine playing at pace where if no wire taken, ball would stop at particular position

subsections.title: Combination Practice Routines
subsections.content: Practicing rushing, croquet strokes, and hoop running as separate stand-alone elements can be useful but has limitations. Each component alone is somewhat boring relative to general accomplishments like TPs. Second, mental aspects of playing a stroke are often connected with the next stroke to come.

figure.description: Typical profile of improvement against practice. Shows skill/performance initially increasing steeply then plateauing, with occasional decreases or performance over short periods before returning to improvement trajectory.

drills.name: Rush from Corner IV Routine
drills.description: Main practice routine combining skills. Starting with rush from corner IV.
drills.purpose: Identify improvement and maintain motivation through 2-ball break style practice

drills.name: 2-Ball Break Practice
drills.description: Developed to work on ability to generate 3-ball breaks from 2-ball break situations. Start with one ball in corner IV and taking croquet from a ball a yard north of it (without 4th ball on lawn). Requires great deal of controlled hoop running to obtain rushes back to corner, digging ball out a little further, and rushing to next hoop.
drills.difficulty: Excellent and extremely stretching routine for improvement once 3-ball break is no longer sufficiently stretching
drills.benefit: Added benefit of introducing difficult choices like whether to take significant wire when running hoop

drills.name: Reg Bamford 2-Ball Break
drills.description: Yet more difficult routine. Instead of all hoops, just repeatedly makes hoop 1 and hoop 3 (before rushing back to hoop 1 continued). Combination of every rush being long and every hoop approach needing to be sound - to allow another controlled hoop for next rush.
drills.challenge: Player must be very good to consistently make more than 3 hoops. How many can you make?

drills.name: Chris Clarke Controlled Hoop Practice
drills.description: Work on controlled hoop running, judging pull, and large croquet strokes.
drills.setup: Give yourself a rush (say with U on R) to hoop 1 from near corner with a pioneer Y at hoop 2
sequence: Playing U, rush R to hoop 1
Run hoop getting the peel position (I up on R and the ball in front sending K to hoop 2-back)
Now place R 2-3 yards away from you, send Y in front of 1-back firmly, attempt 3 points for peeling 1-back and jawsing 1-back
Continue by picking up K from R and play through same process at hoop 3, then K at hoop 4
drills.notes: Practice routine to 'escape ball' from 2-3 feet, easier using 5th turn single-ball style croquet strokes

drills.name: Full 12-Point Rush Practice
drills.setup: Playing U, rush R in front of hoop 1. Approach the hoop sending K in front of 2-back. Make hoop 1 and leave R in the hoop sending K in front of 1-back. Then rush R to 2-back and continue process.
sequence: Rush to hoop 1, approach sending K to 2-back
drills.scoring: 12 point routine tracking all positions and outcomes

drills.name: Stephen Mulliner Practice
drills.description: To discover how some players practice over many days. Worth noting that some players practice very differently. Stephen Mulliner maintains this approach across many days with no practice on 'matchdays'. Approach based on consistent repetition of positions and strokes rather than practice match play.

sections.title: Tactical Improvement
sections.overview: Becoming a better tactician requires developing understanding of several aspects of the game: knowledge of own abilities, knowledge of opponent's abilities, and understanding how to make balanced decisions given data from both.

items: Knowledge of one's own abilities (e.g., probabilities of hitting different length roquets, likelihood of taking break round from various positions)
Understanding how to make balanced decisions, given the data. Not purely about logic, but about gaining sense of how advantageous various positions are, relative to one another

key_concepts.description: Some players are good at overcoming deficiencies on logic-side by emulating good tacticians. 'In a situation like this, I've seen Clarke and Fulford do [X]; therefore I'll do [X]'. But without understanding a tactic, it is impossible to know whether it is a good tactic for you to use.

subsections.title: Fine-tuning
subsections.content: One simple method is to 'fine-tune' a particular sort of leave in a given circumstance. To improve your tactics, it is often best to talk at first as though the opponent is a good robot (ie., they will do what they 'should' do). Gives a particular opponent in mind in terms of their abilities to use your own data to come to a very useful template.

figure.description: Thought process for improving leaves. Flowchart showing: Make own outcome more guaranteed -> Possible Leave -> Evaluate odds of success / Opponent response -> Make opponent's outcome less worthwhile

process: Try to decide what to do - is it a leave or not
Modify the leave to make it easier for opponent to miss (e.g., make it so less clear what they should do)
Repeat steps 1 and 2 until it is unclear which would be the best option for opponent
If considering that the particular opponent is likely to do X against that leave, then consider what they are likely to do, then you can assess whether leave is good or bad

subsections.title: Option-spotting
subsections.content: Fine-tuning a particular leave (or line of play) is all very well, but sometimes the challenging part is to spot a particular (approximate) line of play before it is fine-tuned.
skills: Think about a few situations deeply rather than many shallowly
Laying out positions, thinking through what option should be chosen, then tweaking position to make that option slightly worse - good method of engaging brain in identifying important trade-offs

figure.description: R&Y (both for rover) had just been handled the innings by U&K. Example tactical position with balls at specific locations showing option-spotting situation.

subsections.title: Chess-style Thinking and Openings
subsections.content: Croquet has often been referred to as 'chess on grass' but in many circumstances outcomes are typically stochastic (like rolling dice) rather than deterministic. Nevertheless, some aspects of game are like chess in that deterministic scenarios do occur - commonly in pegged-out games where one move is immediately followed by opponent playing likely known move.
recommendations: Wylie provides excellent discussion of basic opening tactics with Clarke providing update for supershot tactics in Chapter 3

To develop tactics further, recommend finding practice partner of similar ability and playing sequence of little 'opening competitions': first player to make 3 hoops and have established break wins the round
Alternate who goes first. By playing numerous openings back-to-back, mind gets focused on how long tice should be laid, and when best to shoot at tice

subsections.title: Longer-Term Strategies: effects on opponents and oneself
subsections.content: Discussion of how knowledge of what a player will typically do, and thus how you can capitalise on it by tweaking the length of their strokes may have prompted you to think about giving you shorter shots (choosing defensive lines). But not taking the kind of risk that may compound benefit. Finally, having won the previous season or two, playing as you otherwise would but would advise against it.
subsections.key_insight: Your choice of tactical style will influence your physical stroke development. The key routes to improvement over longer-term are tactically optimal and combining playing with a mix of comfort. This is one of the worthwhile attributes - that you gain, that you player commit more, committing to whatever uncertain whether it was best line of play.

subsections.title: Break Hygiene
subsections.content: How does one improve 'break hygiene' (tidiness of breaks; in particular, how easy is each hoop)? Surprising amount of it comes from tactical choices rather than accuracy of play - includes where to send pioneers and pivots, which side of pivot to land on with striker's ball, where to rush it, and how best to double-up with balls at hoops at times when struggling.
key_points: Decision of how firmly to try to run a hoop is a tactical decision
The best choice trades off short-term probability of running hoop (hit it hard and get it damned well through - or the turn ends!) against future break prospects

In a delayed TP, when running 3-back with other balls waiting near penult for second peel, gaining forward rush pays huge dividends and often makes difference between finishing or not for players with handicap of -1 or -1.5

Knowing you need to run hoop with sufficient control not to run beyond other ball, we then find that when approaching the hoop from in front, it is worth approaching to a little closer than normal, as that both gives more hoop control and sends other ball further so provides more stopping room

subsections.title: Pure Logic (and memory of its results)
subsections.content: A final element of tactical ability that is occasionally useful is that of identifying which option is best from a straightforward logical perspective.

examples.situation: Whether you are more likely to roquet a single ball 20 yards away
examples.analysis: A simple diagram shows that there is no difference between required accuracies, so it would make no difference. But note that the 20 yards: this effect will typically be small (though) identifying this sort of thing can be useful

examples.situation: Given choice between shooting at ball a little further away with gut feel vs closer ball
examples.analysis: Logic tells you to hit the right-hand edge of target if half-a-ball off line on either side. Knowing the lawn conditions (7 yards in, etc) can also allow better calculation when comparing shot distances

subsections.memory_aspect: Once you have identified certain logical conclusions, it is worth retaining them in memory. Some players have certainly done this, though I question whether it was the best line of play.

sections.title: Emotions and Confidence
sections.overview: Self-development includes abilities to prepare for playing (and winning!) big matches.

key_concepts.description: Numerous players claim that there aren't 'big' matches - and that there is no such thing as 'stress' - often motivated by their knowledge that, psychologically, there shouldn't be. But if a player were to do things differently in a 'big' match, they are instead doing something different - which is thus likely to be less effective.
Performance is typically an inverted U-shape with respect to stress (or 'arousal').

figure.description: The classic inverted U-shaped curve of performance against stress. Shows performance peaking at moderate stress levels, declining with both too little and too much stress.

key_concepts.description: Practice can be modified to help correct for this: by sometimes imagining oneself in a final, surrounded by crowd interested in the very next stroke. Imagine thousand eyes watching you play the stroke: will it be good? By then playing that stroke, you are practicing under slightly different mental conditions, helping to prepare.

sections.title: Consistency, Measurement and Motivation
sections.overview: Shooting is more consistent to practice than other skills as it is immediately measureable. Performance (or ability) when it comes to shooting is comparatively measureable so the effect of any improvement is also more tangible.

key_concepts.description: I believe that one of the main reasons that people spend more time practicing their shooting than their croquet strokes is that shooting is immediately measurable.
Reg Bamford's style (right photo in Figure 11.5) is clearly to be preferred because so little can go wrong with it by comparison to Ian Burridge's more complex set of body mechanics (left photo).

Having one's hands split can lead to a tiny amount of variation in body mechanics; we'll let it, in this case though, as Reg was actually playing a jump stroke. Thus then, is what a player should strive for when developing a repeatable swing to produce consistent results.

figure.description: Ian Burridge (left) has a more complex set of body mechanics when shooting than Reg Bamford (right). Photos show each player just a moment after having struck a single-ball shot, demonstrating the difference in follow-through positions.

practice_recommendations: Practice can be modified to help correct for needing to perform under pressure

One method is to find a practice partner who is of similar level of ability and set each other croquet stroke challenges: one player lays markers out and the ball closest to each of the markers wins that player a 'point'
Playing with focus on outcome of each ball, overcoming set-back of practice being boring
In a match, croquet strokes often require prioritisation of a certain ball; this can (to some extent) be replicated by giving two points for that nominated ball during the challenge
Having specified the challenge, for each player to get couple of practice attempts at playing the stroke before they play measured attempt for the points

motivation.key_insight: Good practice requires a focus on learning how to focus your mind with short practice sessions, then building from there.
motivation.final_advice: Having read this section, I hope readers will find themselves more motivated to practice and that they are able to. My final advice: don't start 'too much', straight off the bat. Good practice requires a focus on outcome. At present, it is relatively rare for players to compete in World Championships, or turned professional croquet. To achieve that higher standard would be required to elevate players to what they devote to their development.

key_takeaways: Practice what improves match-winning odds, not necessarily what you're worst at
The three key physical skills are: rushing, croquet strokes, and controlled hoop running
Shooting practice is overemphasized by many players
Combination practice routines are more valuable than isolated skill practice
Good tactics require knowledge of both your own and opponent's abilities
Fine-tuning leaves through systematic position tweaking builds tactical understanding
Chess-style deterministic thinking applies mainly to openings and pegged-out games
Break hygiene comes largely from tactical choices, not just execution accuracy
The Yerkes-Dodson law explains optimal stress levels for performance
Consistency in stroke mechanics (like Reg Bamford's style) is preferable to complexity
Measurement and structured challenge games help maintain practice motivation
